job_title: Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Bottom line: the work of organ donation is giving children more time with their parents, spouses more years of marriage, enabling families to have children, ultimately extending life by decades. I have met grandparents who only know their grandchildren because of what we do - they received a heart or a lung or a liver transplant 5, 10, or 20 years ago. They have family members who've since been born that never would've known them.

This is a gift for donor family members too. Donor families are experiencing the worst moments of their lives. They may find the donation process difficult, or resist it altogether in cases when their loved one was on the registry and gave first person authorization. But often they are responding to the terrible, sudden death of someone they love as much as life itself. It's OneLegacy's job to be kind, compassionate, and persistent about donation, because families don't get a do-over once they say no to donation, and neither do the would-be recipients. 

You may read negative reviews about emphasis on "numbers." Those numbers save lives. 1 more organ donor can mean 15 more years of life for 5 different people. No one on the front lines, or in operations has an easy job. But the reason these jobs are so hard is because every organ donor is a life-saver. I think employees can lose sight of that because they don't meet enough recipients. I've had the privilege of meeting many and so I'm proud to work for an OPO that pursues every organ, every time.

They value employees. They put their money where their mouth is, making sure employees are fairly compensated, and taken care of with competitive benefits.
cons:
There is room for improvement with organizational culture. Dedicated employees have often felt voiceless. I can see where efforts are being made, but there's still a lot of room to grow.

Community partnerships at the grassroots level, with churches, organizations, and schools, could go a long way. I know there is an open position for that purpose now, so efforts and growth are happening there too.

If you get hired at OneLegacy, you'll have to work a lot. These are demanding jobs, encountering families at the worst moments of their lives, and coping with witnessing death every day. Don't apply if you aren't ready to work hard for the most important reason I could think of - preventing the premature death and avoidable suffering of other human beings (though most of whom, you'll never know)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
This organization offers amazing exposure into a very niche industry. I was given the opportunity to learn a lot about the different aspects that go into donation -- the family approach process, the actual procurement of tissue, medical review and lastly the support provided to families post donation. It's definitely an invaluable experience and there is much to learn.


Another pro are people who work there. In any organization, some people are terrible/incompetent & some are amazing and way too qualified for what they're doing. I still have great relationships with colleagues I've met there, and I've seen so many develop and leave for better things. Plus, happy hours are always fun!


And lastly, the stories we can tell! It's always funny (and maybe a little depressing) to tell family/friends about the crazy things that happen at OneLegacy. No I don't mean confidential donor stories, but the crazy things management will do and say to their employees. It's unbelievable sometimes! I think it's healthy to vent, laugh about how insane management is and appreciate that we will never have to live the type of life they have that caused them to treat others poorly (unless you stay of course... then sorry).
cons:
Due to the nature of this industry, things are very fast-paced, which isn't necessarily a con because it does improve work ethic and really shows who is capable of adapting to such demands. However, this is added as a con mainly because of how OneLegacy deals with this fast-paced environment. They are vastly understaffed (this is also due to high turnover) and don't particularly reward or acknowledge staff who are high performers. 


Work life balance would be another con. I think it's a great organization for new graduates who want to make a decent paycheck (overtime is always nice too). However, the company does not encourage having a life outside of work, so it's really up to you to decide which is more important. Excessive work also leads to burning out staff, which isn't an issue for OneLegacy if their goal is to utilize staff at their high point. Great method for organizations that want high performers for a short period of time, with zero focus on development. I could see this being beneficial for certain roles at OneLegacy. 


Training is an issue, but they have been moving towards a direction that focuses on this more. As I stated in my pro, it's an invaluable experience, but this "experience" wasn't given to me. Learning is something you have to do on your own. If you are genuinely interested in the industry, you have to take initiative to request to learn about other departments (I've heard of managers denying this, but I was lucky I guess). Also, a lot of what I learned was from Google searches. And oh Wiki is your friend.


Management is probably the biggest con. Many are not qualified for their positions and were merely promoted because of favoritism. Great for the person promoted, but terrible for his/her direct reports. A majority of management is also unprofessional -- it's definitely unheard of of how much they could get away with without HR stepping in. It makes sense that they deal with so many legal battles. It's definitely a very hostile work environment, but a pro to this is learning what you want in a workplace and learning how to be a better person/manager yourself by doing the exact opposite of what they do.


In the end, I thought it was a good experience but it really depends on your priorities. I was willing to give up my life for these demands (mainly to boost my resume) and to earn a boat load of overtime cash. It's definitely not a place you want to stay at long term though -- really not healthy for your soul. I think we all die a little inside while working here, but think about how great it feels when you actually leave!

job_title: Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Bottom line: the work of organ donation is giving children more time with their parents, spouses more years of marriage, enabling families to have children, ultimately extending life by decades. I have met grandparents who only know their grandchildren because of what we do - they received a heart or a lung or a liver transplant 5, 10, or 20 years ago. They have family members who've since been born that never would've known them.

This is a gift for donor family members too. Donor families are experiencing the worst moments of their lives. They may find the donation process difficult, or resist it altogether in cases when their loved one was on the registry and gave first person authorization. But often they are responding to the terrible, sudden death of someone they love as much as life itself. It's OneLegacy's job to be kind, compassionate, and persistent about donation, because families don't get a do-over once they say no to donation, and neither do the would-be recipients. 

You may read negative reviews about emphasis on "numbers." Those numbers save lives. 1 more organ donor can mean 15 more years of life for 5 different people. No one on the front lines, or in operations has an easy job. But the reason these jobs are so hard is because every organ donor is a life-saver. I think employees can lose sight of that because they don't meet enough recipients. I've had the privilege of meeting many and so I'm proud to work for an OPO that pursues every organ, every time.

They value employees. They put their money where their mouth is, making sure employees are fairly compensated, and taken care of with competitive benefits.
cons:
There is room for improvement with organizational culture. Dedicated employees have often felt voiceless. I can see where efforts are being made, but there's still a lot of room to grow.

Community partnerships at the grassroots level, with churches, organizations, and schools, could go a long way. I know there is an open position for that purpose now, so efforts and growth are happening there too.

If you get hired at OneLegacy, you'll have to work a lot. These are demanding jobs, encountering families at the worst moments of their lives, and coping with witnessing death every day. Don't apply if you aren't ready to work hard for the most important reason I could think of - preventing the premature death and avoidable suffering of other human beings (though most of whom, you'll never know)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
This organization offers amazing exposure into a very niche industry. I was given the opportunity to learn a lot about the different aspects that go into donation -- the family approach process, the actual procurement of tissue, medical review and lastly the support provided to families post donation. It's definitely an invaluable experience and there is much to learn.


Another pro are people who work there. In any organization, some people are terrible/incompetent & some are amazing and way too qualified for what they're doing. I still have great relationships with colleagues I've met there, and I've seen so many develop and leave for better things. Plus, happy hours are always fun!


And lastly, the stories we can tell! It's always funny (and maybe a little depressing) to tell family/friends about the crazy things that happen at OneLegacy. No I don't mean confidential donor stories, but the crazy things management will do and say to their employees. It's unbelievable sometimes! I think it's healthy to vent, laugh about how insane management is and appreciate that we will never have to live the type of life they have that caused them to treat others poorly (unless you stay of course... then sorry).
cons:
Due to the nature of this industry, things are very fast-paced, which isn't necessarily a con because it does improve work ethic and really shows who is capable of adapting to such demands. However, this is added as a con mainly because of how OneLegacy deals with this fast-paced environment. They are vastly understaffed (this is also due to high turnover) and don't particularly reward or acknowledge staff who are high performers. 


Work life balance would be another con. I think it's a great organization for new graduates who want to make a decent paycheck (overtime is always nice too). However, the company does not encourage having a life outside of work, so it's really up to you to decide which is more important. Excessive work also leads to burning out staff, which isn't an issue for OneLegacy if their goal is to utilize staff at their high point. Great method for organizations that want high performers for a short period of time, with zero focus on development. I could see this being beneficial for certain roles at OneLegacy. 


Training is an issue, but they have been moving towards a direction that focuses on this more. As I stated in my pro, it's an invaluable experience, but this "experience" wasn't given to me. Learning is something you have to do on your own. If you are genuinely interested in the industry, you have to take initiative to request to learn about other departments (I've heard of managers denying this, but I was lucky I guess). Also, a lot of what I learned was from Google searches. And oh Wiki is your friend.


Management is probably the biggest con. Many are not qualified for their positions and were merely promoted because of favoritism. Great for the person promoted, but terrible for his/her direct reports. A majority of management is also unprofessional -- it's definitely unheard of of how much they could get away with without HR stepping in. It makes sense that they deal with so many legal battles. It's definitely a very hostile work environment, but a pro to this is learning what you want in a workplace and learning how to be a better person/manager yourself by doing the exact opposite of what they do.


In the end, I thought it was a good experience but it really depends on your priorities. I was willing to give up my life for these demands (mainly to boost my resume) and to earn a boat load of overtime cash. It's definitely not a place you want to stay at long term though -- really not healthy for your soul. I think we all die a little inside while working here, but think about how great it feels when you actually leave!

review_title: It will take every last ounce of life out of you
job_title: Technician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Coworkers become family because you never see yours. If you are field staff, you get to be on the road which is better than being stuck in a cubical. Also, the best anatomy lesson of your life when in the surgical environment.
cons: Where do we start. You are viewed as absolutely disposal/replaceable. If you're a veteran employee they'd happily see you leave so they can pay a new college grad a fraction of your wage. If you cause an "event" (a breach in policy), you may or may not get disciplined/fired; it depends if they like you. There are zero growth opportunities. You have to wait for someone to quit or get fired in order to "move up". They tried to offset this by creating new positions but in reality you just become salary and get run even further into the ground. The COO uses intimidation as a suppression tactic and his executives have brought staff to tears. Also, labor laws? Out the window. I cannot tell you how many times I worked 16-20 hr days on cases, slept 3-4 hours and then the phone goes off with your Supervisor saying "Hey, I need you for a case" (a case is a donor btw). Abuse is an understatement. Their compensation for this? A free meal which you pay upfront for and might get reimbursed two months later. Oh, and no on-call pay, they took that away years ago. If you're on the schedule, you only make money if there is a case. No case day=$0.00 dollars earned.

cons: As a non-profit the hourly wages are low. The amount of work is overwhelming at times. With only a half hour lunch available and being in downtown L.A. it is difficult to eat lunch and de-stress, or take care of personal business

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The benefits are decent. The parking is included. Great for someone with no family obligations. The mission of the organization is definitely a positive experience.
cons: They work you to the ground without regard for your personal life. The management does not know how to manage their employees. The main software program they use is DigitalDonor which they paid 2.5 million for and is a terrible excuse of an enterprise database. The user interface is glitchy and not user friendly. The pay is decent for starting out at around $20/hr. But there is no upward mobility. There is no career ladder. The COO, Prasad Garimella, also the CIO which means anything that has to do with the operations or IT goes through him. There is no checks and balances at this company. He is the major problem with this organization. In fact, all of upper management needs to be replaced. This company is money hungry. They make most of their money off of tissue donation. They also started another organization to funnel money into keep it within Onelegacy.  The management do not keep their employees up to date on anything. Many employees know how to manage better than the current managers at Onelegacy.  It is interesting how many employees just get forced to resign and no one knows about it, hence the CFO a couple months ago.
